{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3524580,"name":"","username":"Jakeb","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/e19adc/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-12T12:31:11.912Z","cooked":"

Setup:
I’m using a through bore encoder plugged into a roborio and using the Encoder class. And other than that I’m using a neo vortex, which is going to use the closed loop controller.

In changing the settings for the motor I came across the kAlternateOrExternal Encoder parameter and assume I need to use this. I’m not sure how I’m supposed to set what the motor should use for the encoder instead.

I’ve gotten most of what you have there myself. Just wondering if there’s something special I need to do to tell the code which encoder I want to use other than kExternalOrAlternateEncoder. Something like passing the encoder object to the motor or something along those lines.

Oh, I didn’t realize you had your encoder connected to the roboRIO, sorry, I believe the external or alternate encoder he is talking about is the one connected to the data port of the SPARK MAX or SPARK FLEX.

If you’re using an encoder on the roboRIO, you’ll need to implement the PID control directly on the roboRIO (with a PID controller class), as you can’t pass a process variable to the SPARK.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-02-12T15:02:11.080Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":57,"readers_count":56,"score":46.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":491339,"topic_slug":"alternate-encoder-for-closed-loop-control-rev","display_username":"Luca Carvalho","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":71369,"username":"Jakeb","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/e19adc/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49147,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1156"},"post_url":"/t/alternate-encoder-for-closed-loop-control-rev/491339/6","custom_user_title":"1156","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3524731,"name":"Luca Carvalho","username":"CarvalhoJeo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/carvalhojeo/{size}/249007_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-12T15:03:45.468Z","cooked":"

I don’t know what encoder you’re using, but I would recommend you to connect it on the data port of the SPARK FLEX, using a SPARK Flex Data Port Breakout Cable

Agreed on these comments. You can’t tell the Spark to use something thats not wired directly do it. So your options are either to rewire it so its connected to the Spark, or move your PID control to the rio code.

As an aside… @Jakeb, have you consulted with Rob yet? If not, I highly recommend doing so for local support. If you’re not sure who I’m referring to, ask around and someone will know who he is. I could also stop by, but I’m about twice as far as he is.

Not on this specific issue but he’s the one who encouraged us to use pid control for this. Knowing that we just need use the PIDControl class makes this a bit easier. Just got a bit thrown off by the naming on the kAlternateOrExternalEncoder and assumed incorrectly what it meant.

We’re using a rev through bore encoder and were having issues getting it to give us anything when hooking it up to a spark max ( Still don’t know why and we need the same setup with a sparkmax motor as well for a different purpose ) but from what I understand we need to have it wired as a quadrature encoder as we need positioning over more than one rotation and don’t know how to do that without the roborio.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-02-12T20:17:33.238Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":35,"readers_count":34,"score":7.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":491339,"topic_slug":"alternate-encoder-for-closed-loop-control-rev","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.revrobotics.com/rev-11-1271/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Through Bore Encoder - REV Robotics","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":49147,"username":"CarvalhoJeo","name":"Luca Carvalho","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/carvalhojeo/{size}/249007_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71369,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/alternate-encoder-for-closed-loop-control-rev/491339/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3525281,"name":"","username":"nstrike","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-12T20:18:33.947Z","cooked":"

Just a quick warning; while you can use an alternate encoder for an Elevator, it may be unwise BECAUSE it adds an additional point of failure electrically. If you are sure that you wont have problems with the alternate encoder board coming off or loose, the connections to and from the alternate encoder board are stable and wont come loose when your robot rams into a wall at full speed. Or even worse, another robot going at you at full speed. You are fine, but things tend to get loose.

I would recommend seeding your relative encoder in the Neo/Vortex with a known rotation amount based off of the elevator reading from a range finder or alike. This way the only cable you have to worry about is the encoder cable/port from the motor to the spark.

This is not to say you can’t use alternate encoder boards, YOU CAN. Just use them wisely

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-02-12T20:20:59.446Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":35,"readers_count":34,"score":17.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":491339,"topic_slug":"alternate-encoder-for-closed-loop-control-rev","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51887,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"YAGSL & YASS Creator "},"post_url":"/t/alternate-encoder-for-closed-loop-control-rev/491339/11","custom_user_title":"YAGSL & YASS Creator ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3525283,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-12T20:23:07.976Z","cooked":"
CarvalhoJeo:

If you’re using an encoder on the roboRIO, you’ll need to implement the PID control directly on the roboRIO (with a PID controller class), as you can’t pass a process variable to the SPARK.

An alternative to this approach: If you want the Spark Flex closed loop control, you can use the Absolute encoder connected to the rio. You just need to pass that information to the Spark on bootup, which would look something like this:

absencoder = new DutyCycleEncoder(roborio IO channel);
Subsystem(){ //constructor
  motorconfig.feedbackdevice(kPrimaryEncoder);
  motor.configure(motorconfig....);
  motor.getEncoder().setPosition(absencoder.getPosition());
}

You just need to make sure that the value provided to setPosition represents the expected units configured for motor.getEncoder() (degrees, inches, meters, etc).

Would this work the same with the “Encoder” object which takes two dio ports?

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-02-12T20:32:07.537Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":28,"readers_count":27,"score":10.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":491339,"topic_slug":"alternate-encoder-for-closed-loop-control-rev","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":44763,"username":"tekdemo","name":"Dan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71369,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/alternate-encoder-for-closed-loop-control-rev/491339/13","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3525307,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-12T20:44:50.201Z","cooked":"

That wouldn’t work: an Encoder object is a relative encoder, and doesn’t know anything about the state of the robot on bootup. This is the same system knowledge that the Spark Max relative encoder has. Both systems boot up, and only know that the system is at “zero” since it hasn’t moved yet.

The absolute encoder is different, in that it knows the rotation of a single shaft on bootup.
